newsitem.title: MACAU: Macau hotel "bomb" just a brick, say police.
newsitem.headline: Macau hotel "bomb" just a brick, say police.

text.p: A Macau hotel that was recently the target of a bomb attack was at the centre of a new scare on Thursday, but police said an object thought to be a bomb turned out to be a brick.
A Macau government official earlier said a bomb had been tossed through a restaurant window in the New Century Hotel on the Portuguese-run enclave's Taipa island but had failed to explode.
However police later said what had been thrown was just a brick.
"There was no bomb, no explosion," police spokesman Jose Cruz told a news conference, putting the brick on display.
He said the brick either fell or was thrown through the skylight window of the 600-room hotel's second-floor Japanese restaurant from a room in the hotel or a nearby building.
The China-funded hotel was recently taken over by a local consortium that planned to open a casino.
Recent reports have said rival triad gangs are about to renew a gangland turf war over casino-related rackets.
A spate of firebombings, knifings and drive-by shootings has killed at least 16 people this year in the territory, which returns to Chinese rule in 1999.
The gangs are fighting over shares in illegal loansharking and protection rackets linked to the legal casino business, Macau's biggest industry.
The number of tourists visiting Macau fell 10 percent in May, possibly as a result of violence.
